Financial Statements December&nbsp;31, 2003 </FONT></TD> <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD> <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD> <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">H-1</FONT></TD> <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD> </TR> </TABLE> </CENTER> <P align="center"><FONT size="2">1 </FONT> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <!-- link1 "<FONT size="2">PART I</FONT>" --> <DIV align="left"><A NAME="000"></A></DIV> <P align="center"> <B><FONT size="2">PART I</FONT></B> <DIV>&nbsp;</DIV> <!-- link2 "<FONT size="2">Item 1.Business</FONT>" --> <DIV align="left"><A NAME="001"></A></DIV> <DIV align="left"> <B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;1. <I>Business</I></FONT></B> </DIV> <P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT size="2">Amerada Hess Corporation (the &#147;Registrant&#148;) Delaware corporation, incorporated 1920. The Registrant subsidiaries (collectively referred &#147;Corporation&#148;) explore for, produce, purchase, transport sell crude oil natural gas. These exploration production activities place United States, United Kingdom, Norway, Denmark, Equatorial Guinea, Algeria, Gabon, Indonesia, Thailand, Azerbaijan, countries. The Corporation manufactures, purchases, trades markets refined petroleum energy products. The Corporation owns 50% refinery joint venture United States Virgin Islands, refining facility, terminals retail gasoline stations located East Coast United States. </FONT> <P align="left"> <B><FONT size="2">Exploration Production</FONT></B> <P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, Corporation 646&nbsp;million barrels proved crude oil natural gas liquids reserves compared 782&nbsp;million barrels end 2002. Proved natural gas reserves 2,332&nbsp;million Mcf December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared 2,477&nbsp;million Mcf December&nbsp;31, 2002. These crude oil natural gas reserves included Corporation&#146;s proportionate share reserves equity investees prior years. The decrease proved reserves resulted asset sales production. Proved reserves December&nbsp;31, 2003 include 32% 43%, respectively, crude oil natural gas held production sharing contracts. Of total proved reserves (on barrel oil equivalent basis), 18% located United States, 42% located United Kingdom, Norwegian Danish sectors North Sea remainder located Algeria, Azerbaijan, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Indonesia, Malaysia. On barrel oil equivalent basis, 32% Corporation&#146;s December&nbsp;31, 2003 worldwide proved reserves undeveloped (33% 2002). </FONT> <P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <FONT size="2">Worldwide crude oil natural gas liquids production amounted 259,000&nbsp;barrels day 2003 compared 325,000&nbsp;barrels day 2002. Worldwide natural gas production 683,000&nbsp;Mcf day 2003 compared 754,000&nbsp;Mcf day 2002. The Corporation presently estimates 2004 barrel oil equivalent production approximately 13% 2003. The Corporation developing number oil gas fields inventory domestic foreign drillable prospects. </FONT> <P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <B><I><FONT size="2">United States</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">.&nbsp;&nbsp;Amerada Hess Corporation operates offshore Gulf onshore Texas, Louisiana North Dakota. All provisions program remain effect. </TEXT> </DOCUMENT> <DOCUMENT> <TYPE>EX-13 <SEQUENCE>4 <FILENAME>y93542exv13.htm <DESCRIPTION>2003 REPORT STOCKHOLDERS <TEXT> <HTML> <HEAD> <TITLE>2003 REPORT STOCKHOLDERS</TITLE> </HEAD> <BODY bgcolor="#FFFFFF"> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 14pt">Our Exploration Production efforts focused creating shareholders advancing current development projects, appraising recent discoveries growing proved reserve base. <P align="left" style="font-size: 18pt">EXPLORATION &#038; PRODUCTION <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>PRODUCTION</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In 2003, Amerada Hess produced 373,000 barrels oil equivalent day. Production expected average 325,000 barrels oil equivalent day 2004, reflecting asset sales swaps transacted 2003. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Garden Banks area deepwater Gulf Mexico, total production exceeded 33,000 barrels oil equivalent day 2003. Conger (AHC 37.5%) Baldpate (AHC 50%) key operated assets area. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Onshore, Amerada Hess leading oil producer North Dakota. Through combination horizontal infill drilling stimulation technology, production levels maintained approximately 22,000 barrels oil equivalent day, years. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Seminole San Andres unit West Texas, Amerada Hess industry leader carbon dioxide injection technology increase oil recovery. The carbon dioxide tertiary recovery project commenced 1983 successful recovery projects region. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In North Sea, Amerada Hess large production base including Valhall Field (AHC 28.09%) Norway, South Arne Field (AHC 57.48%) Denmark, Beryl (AHC 22.22%) Schiehallion (AHC 15.67%) fields United Kingdom. In 2003, 55% global oil gas production North Sea. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Ceiba Field (AHC 85%), located Block G Equatorial Guinea, responding favorably water injection expected produce approximately 25,000 net barrels day 2004 compared 22,000 barrels day 2003. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>DEVELOPMENT</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Amerada Hess developing 12 oil gas fields production starting years. These developments expected add 100,000 barrels oil equivalent production day 2006. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">First production Llano Field (AHC 50%) Garden Banks Blocks 385 386 Gulf scheduled mid-2004, initial net production expected reach12,000 barrels oil equivalent day year end. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Block A-18 (AHC 50%) Joint Development Area Thailand, final approval buyer&#146;s pipeline gas plant secured construction commenced half 2003. First production field expected half 2005. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Algeria, net production Gassi El Agreb redevelopment project operated SonaHess, joint operating company Amerada Hess Sonatrach, approximately 20,000 barrels day 2003, increase 30% 2002. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">10 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><IMG src="y93542y9354226.gif" alt="(PHOTO)"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In United Kingdom, production Clair Field (AHC 9.29%) expected 2005 Atlantic (AHC 25%) Cromarty (AHC 90%) gas fields 2006. Combined net production fields expected exceed 25,000 barrels oil equivalent day 2006. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Norwegian North Sea, enhanced recovery Valhall field (AHC 28.09%) begun flank development wells coming onstream 2003 water injection commencing quarter 2004. The Snohvit project (AHC 3.26%), Barents Sea offshore Norway, Europe&#146;s LNG export facility gas production liquefaction begin 2006. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In Equatorial Guinea, results extended appraisal drilling program incorporated development plan Northern Block G discoveries (AHC 85%). It anticipated development plan submitted government approval quarter 2004. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Development giant Azeri, Chirag Guneshli fields (AHC 2.72%), Azerbaijan, schedule. Net production 2,000 barrels oil equivalent day, expected increase 25,000 barrels day 2009. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>EXPLORATION</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Exploration key component future growth. Amerada Hess strong position deep-water Gulf Mexico, leasehold interests 291 blocks 4,000 blocks 3D seismic coverage. In 2003, key discoveries made area: <P> <TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt"> <TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"> <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD> <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD> <TD>Successful appraisal drilling conducted 2002 Shenzi discovery (AHC 28%), Green Canyon Block 654. Further appraisal drilling planned late 2004.</TD> </TR> </TABLE> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In northeastern Thailand, successful appraisal drilled Phu Horm Block E5N (AHC 35%). A flow test completed stabilized gas rate 31.5&nbsp;million cubic feet day. Additional appraisal drilling planned 2004. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Amerada Hess made discovery Block 401c (AHC 60%), Algeria. An extensive seismic program underway, drilling scheduled half 2004. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">11 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 14pt">Refining marketing continues important profit cash generator Corporation, growth opportunities retail energy marketing. In 2003, refining marketing achieved financial performance 10&nbsp;years. <P align="left" style="font-size: 18pt">REFINING &#038; MARKETING <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>REFINING</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The HOVENSA refinery United States Virgin Islands jointly owned Corporation Petroleos de (PDVSA). It largest refineries world. The facility strategically located Caribbean, allowing short crude supply lines Venezuela, easy access U.S. Gulf East Coast product markets. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In 2003, refinery successfully completed year operation 58,000 barrel day coking unit. Gross crude runs refinery averaged 440,000 barrels day 2003, which, combined improved refining margins, resulted significant improvement financial performance versus 2002. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation&#146;s fluid catalytic cracking unit Port Reading, New Jersey produces high-quality, clean-burning gasoline northeast markets. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The facility averaged feedstock runs 54,000 barrels day realized significant improvement gasoline margins 2002. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Both refining facilities continue produce gasoline specifications result emissions U.S. national average. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MARKETING</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Retail</I></B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The retail network leading independent gasoline convenience store marketer East Coast. In 2003, locations built, 10 existing sites upgraded addition EXPRESS convenience stores. EXPRESS stores generally feature fast food offerings proprietary coffee/fountain programs major destinations take-home bulk beverages. EXPRESS gasoline volumes convenience store sales significantly higher industry averages. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">12 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><IMG src="y93542y9354226a.gif" alt="(PHOTO)"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In early 2004, WilcoHess, LLC, joint venture Amerada Hess A.T. Williams Oil Company, completed acquisition 50 retail facilities Service Distributing Company, significantly strengthening brand position growing North Carolina market. With purchase, total number Hess branded retail facilities increased approximately 1,250. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Energy Marketing</I></B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In energy marketing, Corporation major supplier natural gas, fuel oil electricity, 24,000 commercial industrial customer locations primarily East Coast. Cold weather quarter 2003 resulted strong margins demand fuel oil natural gas, significantly improving financial results 2002. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Supply &#038; Terminals</I></B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation operates network twenty-two strategically located petroleum terminals East Coast United States. In addition supply refining assets, well-balanced combination term spot supply contracts flexibility manage product inventories effectively network. In 2003, Corporation leverage network provide customers superior reliability supply unusually cold winter weather. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">13 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL REVIEW<br> Amerada Hess Corporation Consolidated Subsidiaries <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Management&#146;s Discussion Analysis Results Operations Financial Condition</I></B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Executive Overview</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation global integrated energy company operates segments, exploration production (E&#038;P) refining marketing (R&#038;M). The E&#038;P segment explores for, produces sells crude oil natural gas. The R&#038;M segment manufactures, trades markets refined petroleum energy products. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation&#146;s long-term goal E&#038;P segment generate profitable sustainable growth transitioning asset portfolio longer life, lower cost fields, bringing field developments onstream pursuing focused, high impact exploration program. During past years Corporation reshaped E&#038;P asset portfolio by: <P> <TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt"> <TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"> <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD> <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD> <TD>Acquiring exploration, development production assets West Africa Southeast Asia.</TD> </TR> </TABLE> <P> <TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt"> <TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"> <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD> <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD> <TD>Selling higher cost properties predominantly shallow water Gulf North Sea.</TD> </TR> </TABLE> <P> <TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt"> <TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent"> <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD> <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD> <TD>Exchanging interests mature producing assets increased interests development stage assets joint development area deepwater Gulf Mexico.</TD> </TR> </TABLE> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The asset sales exchanges reduced near-term production increased unit operating costs. Production declined 451,000 barrels oil equivalent day 2002 373,000 barrels oil equivalent day 2003. Over 60% reduction resulted absence production assets sold exchanged. The remainder decrease due natural declines poorer expected performance fields United States Equatorial Guinea. Production expected decline 2004 approximately 13% due 2003 asset sales swaps natural declines remaining fields. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation funding twelve development projects expected provide 100,000 barrels oil equivalent day production 2006, offsetting natural declines existing fields providing net production growth. In addition, 2002, Corporation participated deepwater Gulf discoveries provide additional production 2006. As result development projects, Corporation presently estimates production slightly higher 2005 2004 production increase 2006. While Corporation expects developments completed scheduled, development projects subject unforeseen events, technical complexities, delays governmental sanction political instability. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The lower production 2004 expected result higher 2004 unit operating costs due cost reduction initiatives begun 2003 portfolio rationalization. The Corporation believes factors, increasing production developments, reduce unit costs future. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The portfolio reshaping reduced near-term cash flows operations. In response, Corporation hedged approximately 70% 45% 2004 2005 worldwide crude oil production provide secure cash flow fund development projects. Upon completion projects, Corporation expects percentage hedged volumes decrease. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The R&#038;M segment&#146;s financial results improved significantly 2003, principally reflecting higher margins increased sales volumes. The Corporation&#146;s strategic goals R&#038;M maximize financial returns existing assets generate free cash flow. The Corporation opportunistically add retail marketing sites East Coast marketing area. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation&#146;s liquidity financial position significantly improved 2003. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, Corporation&#146;s debt $5&nbsp;billion debt capitalization ratio 54%. During 2003, Corporation generated cash flow $545&nbsp;million asset sales $653&nbsp;million issuance mandatory convertible preferred stock. These actions, combined additional free cash flow profitable operations funding capital expenditures, resulted debt reduction $1.1&nbsp;billion. Year-end debt $3.9&nbsp;billion debt capitalization ratio improved 42.5%. The Corporation $221&nbsp;million debt maturities years, $518&nbsp;million cash hand December&nbsp;31, 2003. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">15 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Consolidated Results Operations</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income continuing operations $467 million 2003 compared loss $245&nbsp;million, including impairments, 2002 income $816&nbsp;million 2001. Production expenses 2003 reflect higher employee benefit, transportation maintenance costs. Production expenses 2002 higher 2001 due increased production higher cost fields, workovers maintenance, higher production volumes. Depreciation, depletion amortization charges lower 2003 2002, reflecting decreased production volumes lower depreciable costs resulting impairments 2002. Depreciation related charges higher 2002 compared 2001, due higher unit costs amortization purchase prices fields Equatorial Guinea, Colombia United States increased production volumes. Exploration expense higher 2003, reflecting increased activity United States Equatorial Guinea, additional lease cost amortization. Exploration expense decreased 2002 compared 2001, principally reflecting improved drilling results. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation&#146;s total unit cost barrel oil equivalent produced increased 2003 2002 compared 2001. During year, Corporation strengthened financial position sales assets issuance preferred stock. noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">NOTES CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br> Amerada Hess Corporation Consolidated Subsidiaries <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>1. SUMMARY SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Nature Business: </I></B>Amerada Hess Corporation subsidiaries (the &#147;Corporation&#148;) engage exploration production, purchase, transportation sale crude oil natural gas. These activities conducted primarily United States, United Kingdom, Norway, Denmark, Equatorial Guinea Algeria. The Corporation oil gas activities Azerbaijan, Gabon, Indonesia, Malaysia, countries. In addition, Corporation manufactures, purchases, transports, trades markets refined petroleum energy products. The Corporation owns 50% HOVENSA L.L.C., refinery joint venture United States Virgin Islands. An additional refining facility, terminals retail gasoline stations located East Coast United States. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In preparing financial statements, management makes estimates assumptions affect reported amounts assets liabilities balance sheet revenues expenses income statement. Actual results differ estimates. Among estimates made management are: oil gas reserves, asset valuations, depreciable lives, pension liabilities, environmental obligations, dismantlement costs income taxes. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Certain information financial statements notes reclassified conform current period presentation. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Principles Consolidation: </I></B>The consolidated financial statements include accounts Amerada Hess Corporation entities Corporation owns 50% voting interest entities Corporation controls. The Corporation&#146;s undivided interests unincorporated oil gas exploration production ventures proportionately consolidated. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Investments affiliated companies, 20% 50% owned, including HOVENSA excluding trading partnership, stated cost acquisition Corporation&#146;s equity undistributed net income acquisition. The change equity net income companies included non-operating income income statement. The Corporation consolidates trading partnership owns 50% voting interest exercises control. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Intercompany transactions accounts eliminated consolidation. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Revenue Recognition: </I></B>The Corporation recognizes revenues sale crude oil, natural gas, petroleum products merchandise title passes customer. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Corporation recognizes revenues production natural gas properties interest based sales customers. Differences natural gas volumes sold Corporation&#146;s share natural gas production material. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Cash Cash Equivalents: </I></B>Cash equivalents consist highly liquid investments, readily convertible cash maturities months acquired. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Inventories: </I></B>Crude oil refined product inventories valued lower average cost market. For inventories valued cost, Corporation principally last-in, first-out (LIFO) inventory method. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Inventories materials supplies valued lower average cost market. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Exploration Development Costs: </I></B>Oil gas exploration production activities accounted successful efforts method. Costs acquiring unproved proved oil gas leasehold acreage, including lease bonuses, brokers&#146; fees related costs, capitalized. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Annual lease rentals exploration expenses, including geological geophysical expenses exploratory dry hole costs, expensed incurred. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Costs drilling equipping productive wells, including development dry holes, related production facilities capitalized. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The costs exploratory wells find oil gas reserves capitalized pending determination proved reserves found. In area requiring major capital expenditure production begin, exploration carried asset sufficient reserves discovered justify completion production well, additional <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">40 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">exploration drilling underway firmly planned. The Corporation capitalize cost exploratory wells year proved reserves found. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Depreciation, Depletion Amortization:</I></B> The Corporation calculates depletion expense acquisition costs proved properties units production method proved oil gas reserves. Depreciation depletion expense oil gas production equipment wells calculated units production method proved developed oil gas reserves. Depreciation plant equipment determined straight-line method based estimated lives. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Provisions impairment undeveloped oil gas leases based periodic evaluations factors. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Asset Retirement Obligations: </I></B>The Corporation recognizes liability fair legally required asset retirement obligations long-lived assets period retirement obligations incurred. The Corporation capitalizes asset retirement costs part carrying amount long-lived assets. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Retirement Property, Plant Equipment: </I></B>Costs property, plant equipment retired disposed of, accumulated reserves, reflected non-operating income. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Impairment Long-Lived Assets: </I></B>The Corporation reviews long-lived assets, including oil gas properties field level, impairment events circumstances carrying amounts recovered. If carrying amounts expected recovered undiscounted future cash flows, assets impaired impairment loss recorded. The amount impairment based estimated fair assets determined discounting anticipated future net cash flows. In case oil gas fields, net present future cash flows based management&#146;s estimate future prices, determined reference recent historical prices published forward prices, applied projected production volumes individual fields discounted rate commensurate risks involved. The projected production volumes represent reserves, including probable reserves, expected produced based stipulated amount capital expenditures. The production volumes, prices timing production consistent internal projections externally reported information. Oil gas prices determining asset impairments generally differ year-end standardized measure discounted future net cash flows. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Impairment Equity Investees: </I></B>The Corporation reviews equity method investments impairment events circumstances temporary decline occurred. The amount impairment based quoted market prices, available, valuation techniques, including discounted cash flows. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Impairment Goodwill: </I></B>In accordance FAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>Goodwill Other Intangible Assets</I>, goodwill amortized; however, tested annually impairment. This impairment test calculated reporting unit level, exploration production segment Corporation&#146;s goodwill. The Corporation identifies potential impairments comparing fair reporting unit book value, including goodwill. If fair reporting unit exceeds carrying amount, goodwill impaired. If carrying exceeds fair value, Corporation calculates impairment loss comparing implied fair goodwill carrying amount. If implied fair goodwill carrying amount, impairment recorded. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Maintenance Repairs: </I></B>The estimated costs major maintenance, including turnarounds Port Reading refining facility, accrued. Other expenditures maintenance repairs charged income incurred. Renewals improvements treated additions property, plant equipment, items replaced treated retirements. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Environmental Expenditures: </I></B>The Corporation capitalizes environmental expenditures increase life efficiency property reduce prevent environmental contamination. The Corporation accrues environmental expenses resulting existing conditions related past operations future costs probable estimable. <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">41 </DIV> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P> <DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif"> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Employee Stock Options Nonvested Common Stock (Restricted Stock) Awards: </I></B>The Corporation intrinsic method account employee stock options. Because exercise prices employee stock options equal exceed market price stock date grant, Corporation recognize compensation expense. The pro forma financial information presents effect net income earnings share Corporation fair method. ACCOUNTING CHANGE</B> <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2003, Corporation changed method accounting asset retirement obligations required FAS No.&nbsp;143, <I>Accounting Asset Retirement Obligations. </I>Previously, Corporation accrued estimated costs dismantlement, restoration abandonment, estimated salvage values, offshore oil gas production platforms pipelines units-of-production method. This cost reported component depreciation expense accumulated depreciation. Using accounting method required FAS No.&nbsp;143, Corporation recognizes liability fair legally required asset retirement obligations long-lived assets period retirement obligations incurred. The Corporation capitalizes asset retirement costs part carrying amount long-lived assets. <P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The cumulative effect change prior years resulted credit income $7&nbsp;million $.07 share, basic diluted.
